channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Chasing the Lure of a Royal Past With Greyhound Racing in Punjab
item.description: By racing dogs in an unmarked field, wealthy Sikh landowners — some of them gas station moguls in the United States — are trying to keep alive the ways of the maharajahs.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Men with their greyhounds during last week’s meet in Faridkot, in Punjab.

item.title: América : Los actores Sean Penn y Kate del Castillo entrevistaron a ‘El Chapo’ en México para la revista Rolling Stone
item.description: La entrevista con Rolling Stone, probablemente la primera que el narcotraficante ha concedido en décadas, se llevó a cabo en varios encuentros.
item.dc:creator: Por RAVI SOMAIYA
item.media:description: El actor Sean Penn, izquierda, y el narcotraficante Joaquín Guzmán Loera en una foto tomada por motivos de autenticación durante una entrevista para la revista Rolling Stone.

item.title: Sean Penn Sat for Secret Interview With ‘El Chapo,’ Mexican Drug Lord
item.description: Before he was captured, Joaquín Guzmán Loera met with the actor in his jungle hide-out for seven hours in October and spoke about his his empire, Donald Trump and the movie business for Rolling Stone.
item.dc:creator: RAVI SOMAIYA
item.media:description: The actor Sean Penn, left, and the drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera in a photo taken for interview authentication purposes.

item.title: Mexico May Extradite Drug Kingpin Known as El Chapo
item.description: Mexican officials said the process to extradite Joaquín Guzmán Loera could take months, and his lawyers are expected to fight it.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: A photo released on Friday by a Mexican website, Plaza de Armas, of Mr. Guzmán, who was recaptured in Los Mochis.

item.title: Taliban Step Up Urban Assaults, Testing the Mettle of Afghan Forces
item.description: The government is trying to reassure citizens while the Taliban appears to be trying to strengthen its hand before peace talks.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and AHMAD SHAKIB
item.media:description: An Afghan policeman inspecting a building used by insurgents to carry out an attack near the Indian Consulate in Mazar-i-Sharif.

item.title: Cubans, Fearing Loss of Favored Status in U.S., Rush to Make an Arduous Journey
item.description: Worried that an advantage in immigration law may end as the United States restores relations with their country, many Cubans have rushed off the island, only to be stalled in Central America.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gretchen López dreamed of being able to send money to her mother in Cuba to renovate her crumbling, but she got stuck in rural Costa Rica, alongside hundreds of other Cubans while trying to make a perilous slog by land through eight countries to reach the United States.

item.title: A Tumultuous Housing Program in Algeria
item.description: A government housing program in Algeria is one of the most ambitious in the region, but critics say it is creating as many problems as it solves.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Les Dunes, a tenement building in Algiers.

item.title: All-Bedouin Tech Company Hints at Shift in Israel
item.description: Companies like Sadel Tech and government initiatives are aiming to bring more young Arabs into the technology work force.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rabaa Al-Hawashleh, 24, with her mother, sister and brother at their home in Abu Qreinat, Israel. Ms. Hawashleh provides quality control for software programs at Sadel Tech.

item.title: Separatists in Catalonia Select Leader to Avoid Vote
item.description: The agreement ends more than three months of feuding among separatist parties over who should lead the next regional government.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: After Assaults in Cologne, Merkel Proposes Tougher Asylum Laws
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel’s proposal came as the city bristled with violent tension following New Year’s Eve assaults on scores of women.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Egypt’s Parliament Prepares for Session With Some Familiar Names
item.description: Although some of the most reviled Mubarak-era figures were barred from the election, several other officials or close relatives have seen their political fortunes restored.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: A new Parliament will be seated on Sunday for the first time in three years. It has 596 seats, the most in Egypt’s history.

item.title: Egypt’s President Turns to Religion to Bolster His Authority
item.description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, who came to power after ousting a leader of the Muslim Brotherhood, has increasingly used religion to justify a crackdown on his rivals.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt at an economic development conference last March in Sharm el Sheikh. In recent months he has used religion to justify a crackdown on his rivals.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Myanmar’s Peace Prize Winner and Crimes Against Humanity
item.description: Aung San Suu Kyi is taking power with silence on the government’s abuse of the Rohingya minority.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KRISTOF
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children near their homes in one of the concentration camps where Myanmar has locked away a Muslim minority called the Rohingya.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Germany on the Brink
item.description: How today’s migration could unsettle Europe for generations.
item.dc:creator: ROSS DOUTHAT

item.title: Mexican Drug Lord’s Quest for Movie Fame Helped Lead to Capture, Official Says
item.description: With a beauty queen wife and two Houdini-like escapes from prison under his belt, Mr. Guzmán, known by the nickname El Chapo, wanted to make his own biopic.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Mexico is considering extraditing Joaquín Guzmán Loera, or El Chapo, to the United States, officials said.

item.title: ‘Broken System’ Allows ISIS to Profit From Looted Antiquities
item.description: A police raid in Bulgaria was heralded as a rare success against the trafficking of antiquities, but it also highlighted the barriers officials face.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS and NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A museum in the Bulgarian capital, Sofia. The Bulgarian police seized 9,000 artifacts in the northeastern region of Shumen in March 2015, including some that may have been smuggled out of Iraq, possibly during the time the Islamic State was in control.

item.title: Chinese Markets Rise After Volatile Opening
item.description: Shares in both Shanghai and Shenzhen closed up on Friday despite a shaky opening hour, with sharp drops and rises within minutes of each other.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG
item.media:description: The People's Bank of China, the country's central bank, in Beijing. The central bank strengthened its currency, the renminbi, on Friday morning.

item.title: News Executives Push to Free Jason Rezaian, Reporter Held in Iran
item.description: The executives said Iran should recognize that independent journalism was “a fundamental human right” and free Mr. Rezaian, a Washington Post reporter.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: News Analysis: With Nuclear Test, North Korea’s Leader Asserts Role of Instigator
item.description: Kim Jong-un is often dismissed as erratic, but this week he increased tensions between the United States and China and put more pressure on South Korea.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: North Koreans celebrating in Pyongyang on Friday after what officials said was a “successful hydrogen bomb” test.

item.title: British Man Admits Past in Terror Cell in Yemen
item.description: Minh Quang Pham pleaded guilty in federal court in Manhattan to three terrorism-related counts.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER
